Vaporized hydrogen peroxide (VHP) holds great promise for the decontamination of space environment. Nevertheless, following the decontamination process, highly concentrated VHP within confined spaces is harmful to the human body. Hence, trace Pt-loading (0.57 wt%) transition metal hydroxides nanosheets anchored on Ni foam (Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF) were prepared for VHP decomposition. Importantly, a strong electronic interaction between NiAlCrFe layer double hydroxides (NiAlCrFe-LDHs) and Pt was evidenced by XPS. Meanwhile, unique nanosheet-like morphology and rich mesoporous structure endow the catalyst with excellent performance. The catalytic activity of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF is approximately twice that of NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF and seven times that of Pt/NF. The improved catalytic efficiency of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF results from the reduction in energy barrier for VHP decomposition reaction caused by the introduction of trace Pt. After ten recycling experiments, this catalyst still shows good durability with no significant deterioration in VHP decomposition efficiency. Finally, the growth mechanism of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF was also proposed and discussed. Graphical Abstract Keywords Vaporized hydrogen peroxide (VHP) Catalytic decomposition Transition metal hydroxides Trace Pt Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Vaporized hydrogen peroxide (VHP) holds great promise for the decontamination of space environment due to its broad-spectrum bactericidal efficiency, good distribution uniformity and minimal corrosiveness. It can meet the sterilization needs of precision instruments and the internal spaces of vehicles, aircrafts and ships, and it can also be applied for disinfection in environments like medical devices, operating rooms, and wards [1–3]. The whole process of VHP decontamination consists of three steps. The first step is the vaporization of liquid H2O2, the second step is the diffusion of VHP into the disinfection space and the last step is VHP removal. Nevertheless, following the whole decontamination process, highly concentrated VHP within confined spaces poses significant hazards, including the risk of explosion and the potential for irreversible harm to human body [4], therefore, it needs to be removed to a concentration below 1 ppm for long term exposure to VHP. The VHP is thermodynamically unstable and tends to self-decomposition, but the self-decomposition process is very slow. Traditional methods for the VHP removal such as dilution by clean air [5], physical adsorption [6], and bio-enzymatic decomposition [7] cannot satisfy the application requirements owing to low removal efficiency, secondary pollution and complex operation. Catalytic decomposition of VHP into water and oxygen is regarded to be an effective, simple and safe method for the removal of residual VHP, and developing extremely effective and inexpensive catalysts is of significant importance for achieving this process. Nanostructured noble metal materials exhibit superior performance for catalytic reactions [8–10]. To date, Pt has been proven to be the most effective active component for VHP decomposition [11–13], while its massive utilization is limited owing to the intrinsic disadvantages of high cost, scarcity and instability [14–17]. Recently, transition metal-based catalysts have received considerable interest due to their affordable cost, plentiful supply, adjustable d-orbits and chemical structures[18–23]. Among them, transition metal hydroxides, especially Ni/Al/Cr/Fe-based multinary hydroxides with rich valence states, have been extensively investigated and exhibited catalytically active for VHP decomposition [18,24–30]. However, the catalytic efficiency of catalysts based on transition metals is generally poorer than that of Pt-based catalysts. It is reported that tuning compositions of materials through integrating different components would create new active centers and effectively improve the intrinsic activity and durability of catalytic materials [31]. Therefore, the integration of precious metals into inexpensive transition metal hydroxides will take full advantage of their merits, accelerating the VHP decomposition rate and greatly reducing production costs [32–34]. Moreover, the substrates with a large surface area and a self-supported three-dimensional (3D) porous structure can maximize the contact of VHP and catalysts, and facilitate gas flow [35]. Nickel foam (NF) displays a large surface area, extremely low pressure drop and excellent mechanical robustness in highly active exothermic or endothermic catalytic reactions and is considered to be an ideal 3D substrate for supporting noble metals and transition metal hydroxides [36–38]. In this study, through a facile one-pot hydrothermal process, we constructed trace Pt-loading transition metal hydroxides nanosheets grown on NF (Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF) to facilitate VHP decomposition. The morphology, structure and surface electronic properties of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF were thoroughly characterized via a comprehensive set of techniques. Furthermore, the catalytic activity and durability of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF were studied and its growth mechanism was also explored. The Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF catalyst with trace Pt loading exhibits outstanding catalytic activity and stability owing to the synergistic interaction of NiAlCrFe layer double hydroxides (NiAlCrFe-LDHs) and Pt NPs. The formation of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs nanosheets follows a dissolution-precipitation process and spontaneous reduction of Pt nanoparticles. This study provides a simple method for manufacturing highly active catalysts for VHP decomposition, which is expected to have great application prospects in the future. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and materials The Ni foams (NFs) with a size of 50 × 50 × 10 mm and a PPI of 30 were purchased from Kunshan Weidasi Electronics Co., Ltd., China. Ethanol (C2H5OH), Acetone (CH3COCH), Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), hydrochloric acid (HCl), urea (CO(NH2)2), iron nitrate hydrate (Fe(NO3)3 2O), chromium nitrate hydrate (Cr(NO3)3 2O) and aluminum nitrate hydrate (Al(NO3)3 2O) were sourced from Tianjin Yongda Co., Ltd., China. Sodium hexachloroplatinate (Na2PtCl6) was bought from Sigma-Aldrich Corporation, USA. Each solution was prepared using Millipore ultrapure water. 2.2 Preparation of the catalyst The preparation process of catalysts is illustrated in Scheme 1, in which the catalysts were successfully fabricated through a simple one-pot hydrothermal route [39]. Prior to synthesis of the precursors, the NFs were successively immersed in acetone, ethanol and 3 M HCl for 20 min, followed by washing with ultrapure water to eliminate the oxide layer and other impurities. Subsequently, four NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF samples with different molar amounts of metal precursors were prepared via 150 mL of solutions containing (2, 4, 6, 8) mmol of Al(NO3)3 2O, (3, 6, 9, 12)mmol of Cr(NO3)3·9H2O, (2, 4, 6, 8) mmol of Fe(NO3)3 2O and 88.25 mmol of CO(NH2)2, respectively. The cleaned NFs were placed in 250 mL Teflon-lined autoclaves containing the above solutions and the hydrothermal reaction occurs at 120 °C for 10 h. The hydrothermal products were repeatedly rinsed with ultrapure water and ethanol for several times and maintained at 60 °C in a vacuum oven. The corresponding final samples were designated as NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-1, NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-2, NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-3, NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-4, respectively. Accordingly, the molar amount of the transition metal precursors was optimized to obtain the best catalytic material for VHP decomposition. The NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-3 shows the best catalytic activity, and it was simply denoted as NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF. Following the process above, the Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF was prepared via the solution of 0.11 mmol of Na2PtCl6, 6 mmol of Al(NO3)3 2O, 9 mmol of Cr(NO3)3 2O, 6 mmol of Fe(NO3)3 2O and 88.25 mmol of CO(NH2)2 and the Pt/NF was also synthesized via the solution of 0.11 mmol of Na2PtCl6 and 88.25 mmol of CO(NH2)2. 2.3 Characterizations The SEM combined with EDS (Hitachi Regulus 8100, Japan) was utilized to measure the morphology and element distribution of as-synthesized catalysts. The morphology and microstructure were further explored using the TEM, HRTEM, SAED, and HAADF-STEM measurements (JEOL JEM F200, Japan). Powder XRD (Rigaku SmartLab SE, Japan) was employed to analyze the crystal structure of catalysts. The bonded states in catalysts were detected by FTIR (Thermo Scientific Nicolet 6700, USA). The BET and BJH methods (Micromeritics ASAP 2460, USA) were applied to determine the pore-size distributions and nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms. XPS (Shimadzu Kratos AXIS Supra, Japan) was conducted to measure the electronic properties and surface element composition of as-synthesized catalysts under an excitation voltage of 12.5 kV with an Al Kα source. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterizations The SEM combined with EDS was utilized to investigate the morphology and element distribution of the Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF. The SEM images of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF in Fig. 1(a-c) display an interconnected network structure which is formed by nanosheets vertically distributed on the surface of NF. This unique structure with a large surface area favors electron transfer and thus enhances intrinsic catalytic activity. Furthermore, the EDS spectrum reveals the contents of Al, Cr, Fe, Ni, Pt, and O are 8.39, 12.75, 7.77, 44.41, 0.57 and 26.11 wt%, respectively, determining the existence of extremely low Pt (Fig. 1d). The EDS mapping images (Fig. 1(e-j)) show a homogeneous co-existence of all elements on the entire NF surface. Meanwhile, the ICP-MS demonstrates the content of Pt is approximately 0.59 wt%, further confirming the low content of Pt in Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF (Table S1). The TEM, HRTEM and SAED measurements were conducted to further explore the morphology and microstructure of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF. As shown in Fig. 2a, the TEM image of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF also confirms the presence of nanosheet-like morphology, in line with SEM results presented in Fig. 1(a-c). From the HRTEM image of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF, the lattice spacings of 0.262, 0.247 and 0.208 nm correspond to the (012) crystallographic plane of NiFe LDHs [40,41], the (009) crystallographic plane of NiAl LDHs and the (111) crystallographic plane of Ni [42], respectively, indicating the successful formation of transition metal hydroxides (Fig. 2b). The SAED pattern also shows polycrystalline rings of NiFe LDHs (012), NiAl LDHs (009) and FeAl LDHs (603), further proving the presence of transition metal hydroxides (Fig. 2c). In addition, the HAADF-STEM image coupled with related EDS analysis (Fig. 2(d-j)) also verifies the homogeneous distribution of all elements and determine that Pt nanoparticles are grown on transition metal hydroxides nanosheets. In addition, the crystal structure of NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF and Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF was characterized employing XRD. Fig. 3a exhibits the XRD pattern of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF, from which it can be found that Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF is mainly composed of NiAl LDHs, NiFe LDHs, FeAl LDHs, and metallic Ni and Pt, consistent with the TEM analysis displayed in Fig. 2. The XRD pattern of NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF shows nearly identical diffraction peaks to Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF apart from the absence of Pt and FeO(OH) diffraction peaks. The diffraction peaks at 11.6°, 23.2°, 34.9°, 39.3°, and 61.9° originate from (003), (006), (009), (105), and (112) crystal planes of NiAl LDHs (PDF#48–0593) [43,44], respectively. The diffraction peaks at 11.6°, 23.2°, 34.9°, 39.3°, and 65.8° are attributed to the (003), (006), (012), (015), and (116) crystal planes of NiFe LDHs (PDF#40–0215)[41,45–48], respectively. The diffraction peaks at 46.7°and 60.7° are assigned to (228) and (603) crystal planes of FeAl LDHs (PDF#51–1527), respectively. The three diffraction peaks at 44.5°, 51.9° and 76.3° are ascribed to the NF (PDF#03–1051). Notably, the small peaks at 27.7° and 42.2° corresponding to the (301) plane of FeO(OH) (PDF#22–0353) and the (111) plane of Pt (PDF#01–1194) only appear in the XRD pattern of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF. Besides, no peaks associated with Cr are observed in NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF and Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF, suggesting the amorphous nature of Cr element. More importantly, both Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF and NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF show a negative shift compared to standard NiAl LDHs peak positions and a positive shift relative to standard NiFe LDHs peak positions, indicating the change in lattice spacing caused by incorporation of Cr. To deeply understand the structural nature, the bonded states of the Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF were detected by FTIR spectrum (Fig. 3b). The absorption peak at 3639 cm−1 derives from the vibration of -OH from Metal(OH)x. Two broad bands at 1629 and 3423 cm−1 are ascribed to the bending and stretching vibrations of interlayer H2O of LDHs [49]. The vibration of NO 3 − can be obviously observed at 1384 cm−1 [50]. Noteworthily, the peak at 1353 cm−1 assignable to vibration of CO 3 2 − evidences co-presence of CO 3 2 − [51]. Besides, the IR band in the range of 500–650 cm−1 splits into two peaks which are assigned to the stretching vibration of Metal-O [52,53]. The FT-IR results further demonstrate the formation of a typical LDHs structure with NO 3 − and some CO 3 2 − as interlayer anions to compensating extra positive charges, in line with the TEM, XRD and XPS results. To further assess the pore-size distribution and specific surface area of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF, the active components were peeled off the NF substrate and tested in the form of powder by BET. In Fig. 3c, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF shows a typical IV isotherm with a hysteresis loop ranging between 0.4 P/P0 and 1.0 P/P0, indicating the existence of mesopores, possibly formed by the interconnected nanosheets. Furthermore, the pore-size distribution of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF (Fig. 3d) shows that the pore size ranges from 4 nm to 10 nm, further confirming the mesoporous structure of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF. The BJH desorption pore volume and BET surface area of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF are 0.353 cm3/g and 305.1532 m²/g, respectively. The unique mesoporous architecture coupled with a large BET surface area significantly increases the contact area of VHP and catalyst, thus facilitating redox reaction between VHP and active components on the catalyst surface. XPS was conducted to measure the electronic properties and surface element composition of NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF and Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF. The XPS survey spectrum of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF shown in Fig. S1 identifies Al, Cr, Fe, Ni, Pt, and O elements, which is consistent with ICP-MS and EDS analysis. In Fig. 4a, for NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF, two peaks that emerged at 67.84 and 73.83 eV are attributed to Ni 3p, and Al 2p, respectively. After the incorporation of Pt, two new peaks at 71.46 and 74.66 eV assignable to Pt0 7/2 and Pt0 4f5/2 are observed in the Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF, which confirms the presence of metallic Pt[54,55]. Moreover, the Pt0 7/2 and Pt0 5/2 peaks of Pt@NiAolCrFe-LDHs/NF shift positively by 0.46 eV relative to standard Pt0 7/2 (71.00 eV) and Pt0 7/2 (74.20 eV), indicating the interracially electronic effect between Pt and NiAlCrFe-LDHs. The Cr 2p spectrum of NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF (Fig. 4b) shows peaks at 577.03, 586.41 and 581.56 eV assignable to the Cr3+ 2p3/2, Cr3+ 2p1/2 and Cr6+ 2p3/2, respectively[56,57]. However, no peak associated with Cr6+ is observed in that of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF, verifying the formation of Cr(Ⅲ) hydroxide. The Fe 2p region of the NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF and Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF is deconvoluted into three peaks (Fig. 4c). For Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF, the peaks located at 707.06, 713.17 and 723.67 eV are assigned to Fe2+ 2p3/2, Fe3+ 2p3/2, and Fe3+ 2p1/2, respectively, revealing the Fe element exists in two valence states (+2 and +3) [56,58]. Compared with NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF, the Fe3+ 2p3/2 peak of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF exhibits a negative shift of 1.45 eV, further proving electron depletion after Pt adding. From the Ni 2p spectrum of NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF presented in Fig. 4d, two pairs of spin-orbit peaks are observed with 855.73 and 873.29 eV (Ni2+ 2p3/2 and Ni2+ 2p1/2) and 861.96 and 873.29 eV (Ni2+ 2p3/2 Sat. and Ni2+ 2p1/2 Sat.). Furthermore, the remaining peak at 880.39 eV is attributed to Ni2+ 2p1/2 Sat. [59,60]. It’s worth noting that nearly similar Ni 2p peaks can be found in Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF, implying the introduction of Pt does not affect the coordination environment of Ni and its chemical valence. The O 1 s spectrum (Fig. 4e) is fitted into three peaks corresponding to metal oxides (529.28 eV), Metal(OH)x (531.17 eV) and C-O (532.08 eV), respectively. Notably, by simulating the fitted peak area, the contents of metal oxides, Metal(OH)x and C-O are determined to be 5.16, 63.92, and 30.92 at%, respectively, further confirming that the metal elements are present mainly in the form of hydroxides[61]. The C 1 s spectrum (Fig. 4 f) is divided into three peaks. The first peak at 284.8 eV corresponds to C-C and the other two are attributed to CO 3 2 − in LDHs, suggesting the existence of analogous LDHs with CO 3 2 − as interlayer anions [61,62]. In general, there still exists a strong electronic interaction on heterointerfaces of NiAlCrFe-LDHs and Pt, effectively adjusting the electronic structure of catalyst and thus accelerating the reaction kinetics of VHP decomposition. Based on all above characterizations, it is verified that the catalyst consists of low Pt-loading transition metal hydroxides nanosheets. 3.2 Growth mechanism of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs nanosheets The growth mechanism of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs nanosheets follows a dissolution-precipitation process and spontaneous reduction of Pt nanoparticles. The main reactions can be summarized as Eq.1-10. It is known that Al(NO3)3, Cr(NO3)3, and Fe(NO3)3 are hydrolyzed readily in water [63], producing hydrated metal(Al, Cr, and Fe) hydroxides and hydrogen ions (H+) and making the solution acidic (Eq.1). The NF is chemically etched by the acid condition in combination with NO 3 − to form Ni2+ ions (Eq.2). Meanwhile, due to a energetically preferable process (ΔE = EFe(Ⅲ)/(II) − ENi(II)/(0) > 0, EFe(Ⅲ)/(II) = 0.771 V, ENi(II)/(0) = −0.257 V), the NF also acts as a reducing agent to effectively reduce partial Fe3+ ions to Fe2+ ions (Eq.3) [64]. The etched NF surface exhibits a porous structure (Fig. S2), which enhances the binding strength between substrate and active components and is favorable to the loading of active components. In addition, the precipitator plays a major role during the hydrothermal process. The urea is used as a precipitating agent because hydrolysis of urea can slowly release hydroxide ions ( OH − ) and carbonate ions ( CO 3 2 − ) at high temperature and pressure (Eqs.4–6) [65]. The formation of OH − not only provides an alkaline environment, resulting in the precipitation of the analogous LDHs, but also slows down the dissolution rate of NF, maintaining its mechanical robustness. When Ni2+ and Fe2+ ions co-precipitate with hydrated metal (Al, Cr, and Fe) hydroxides, CO 3 2 − and NO 3 − species are trapped within the intergallery space to balance the charge and consequently forming NiAlCrFe-LDHs nanosheets (Eq.7) [66,67]. Meanwhile, the NH 3 formed by hydrolysis of urea also coordinates with transition metal cations ( M n + = Ni2+, Fe2+, Al3+, Cr3+ and Fe3+) to form M ( NH 3 ) x n + (Eq.8). Transition metal cations with higher precipitation rates are more likely to coordinate with NH 3 , thus regulating the precipitation rates of different metal ions and allowing uniform co-precipitation of Ni2+ and Fe2+ with hydrated metal (Al, Cr, and Fe) hydroxides. Moreover, metallic Pt is generated by a redox reaction of Pt4+ and NF (Eq.9), owing to much higher EPt(Ⅳ)/(0) (0.68 V) than ENi(II)/(0) (−0.257 V) [68] and then Pt nanoparticles are incorporated into the lattice of NiAlCrFe-LDHs to form Pt-loading NiAlCrFe-LDHs nanosheets (Eq.10). (1) Al 3 + / Cr 3 + / Fe 3 + + ( x + y ) H 2 O → Al / Cr / Fe ( OH ) x ( H 2 O ) y ( 3 − x ) + + x H + (2) 3 Ni + 8 H + + 2 NO 3 − → 3 Ni 2 + + 2 NO + 4 H 2 O (3) Ni + 2 Fe 3 + → Ni 2 + + 2 Fe 2 + (4) CO ( NH ) 2 + 4 H 2 O → H 2 CO 3 + 2 NH 3 · H 2 O (5) H 2 CO 3 ⇌ 2 H + + CO 3 2 − (6) NH 3 + H 2 O ⇌ NH 3 · H 2 O ⇌ NH 4 + + OH − (7) Ni 2 + + Fe 2 + + Al / Cr / Fe ( OH ) x ( H 2 O ) y ( 3 − x ) + + OH − + CO 3 2 − + NO 3 − → NiAlCrFe − LDHs (8) Ni 2 + / Al 3 + / Cr 3 + / Fe 3 + + x NH 3 → Ni ( NH 3 ) x 2 + / Fe ( NH 3 ) x 2 + / Al ( NH 3 ) x 3 + / Cr ( NH 3 ) x 3 + / Fe ( NH 3 ) x 3 + (9) Pt 4 + + 2 Ni → Pt + 2 Ni 2 + (10) Pt + NiAlCrFe − LDHs → Pt@NiAlCrFe − LDHs 3.3 VHP decomposition performance The VHP decomposition activities of various samples were evaluated by catalytic decomposition time and the detailed experimental procedure is shown in Text S1 and Fig. S3. Fig. 5(a, b) compared the VHP decomposition activities of NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF samples with various molar amounts of metal precursors. It is observed that the pure NF shows limited VHP decomposition activity, while the other catalysts show relatively higher VHP decomposition activity, implying the catalytic activity is primarily dependent on active components anchored on the surface of NF substrate. Additionally, the catalytic decomposition time initially decreases with the molar amount of metal precursors increasing and subsequently increases, which means that excessive metal precursors result in the deterioration of catalytic efficiency. The NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-3 shows the optimal catalytic activity for VHP decomposition and only 28 min is required to reduce the VHP concentration to less than 1 ppm. Thus, the trace Pt is introduced into the NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-3. Fig. 5(c, d) exhibits the VHP decomposition activities of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF and control samples including NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF and Pt/NF. It can be seen that the catalytic activity of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF is approximately twice that of NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF and seven times that of Pt/NF, demonstrating the introduction of a trace amount of Pt significantly enhances catalytic activity toward VHP decomposition. Meanwhile, the above results also evidence the existence of the synergistic interaction between NiAlCrFe-LDHs and Pt nanoparticles. Long-term durability is also very crucial for catalyst commercialization. The durability of the Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF sample was investigated through ten recycling experiments. Fig. 6(a, b) shows a fluctuating trend of catalytic decomposition time in the range of 28 ∼ 40 min and the average time of catalytic decomposition for ten recycling tests is 35 min. The VHP is thermodynamically unstable, so catalytic decomposition process of VHP is often accompanied by self-decomposition. The self-decomposition process is influenced by environmental factors such as ambient temperature, humidity and light. Therefore, the catalytic decomposition time varies with slight changes in environmental factors and the fluctuation range of about 10 min is within the normal error range. Meanwhile, no significant performance deterioration is observed after ten recycling tests, demonstrating the remarkable catalytic stability of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF. The elemental composition and surface morphology of the sample after testing were also characterized by SEM and EDS. The SEM image (Fig. S5) shows the morphology of the Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF has no obvious change and still maintains an intact nanosheet structure. EDS results (Fig. S6 and Table S2) exhibit only a trace reduction in the content of metal elements. All of the above results indicate that the catalyst has good structural stability. In addition, the sonication experiment with half an hour shows that the weight of catalyst after three sonication tests has no significant change compared to the initial weight, confirming the active components were firmly attached to the NF surface (Table S3). 3.4 Source of the excellent performance of the Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF To investigate the differences in the performance of catalysts prepared with different precursor usage, the morphology, pore structure and mass loading of active components of a series of control samples were characterized. Noteworthily, the morphology of the catalyst is of significant importance for its intrinsic catalytic activity. The SEM images of the NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF catalysts with different molar amounts of metal precursors are shown in Fig. 7(a-d). It is found the size of nanosheets increases with an increase in the molar amount of metal precursors. The average nanosheet thickness of NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-1, NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-2, NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-3 and NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-4 are 6.16, 11.69, 14.61, 19.01 nm, respectively (Table S4). In NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-1 and NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-2, the nanosheets are too thin and small to notably increase the surface area, resulting in the inadequate interaction with VHP. The lower intrinsic activity of NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-4 is due to the aggregation of nanosheets with a higher thickness, leading to insufficient exposure of active sites. Therefore, NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-3 with a suitable size and density possesses best intrinsic catalytic activity. In addition, the mass loading of active components continues to increase as the molar amount of metal precursors increases. The mass loading of NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-1, NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-2, NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-3 and NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-4 are 3.43, 11.73, 21.29, 17.42 mg/cm2, respectively. The increased thickness of the catalytic layer on the surface of NF also further verifies an increase in mass loading (Fig. S4 and Table S5). The increased mass loading of active components could create more active sites for VHP decomposition, while excessive loading would cause the inadequate utilization of NiAlCrFe-LDHs nanosheets. Thus, NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-3 with an appropriate mass loading is more favorable for VHP decomposition. Meanwhile, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF samples with various molar amounts of metal precursors ( Fig. 8(a-d)) show that all isotherms have typical IV sorption behavior with an obvious type-H3 hysteresis loop, implying the presence of mesopores. From the insets in Fig. 8(a-d), it is found that the average pore sizes of NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-1, NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-2, NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-3 and NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-4 are 7.3, 9.2, 7.1, 9.0 nm, respectively, further confirming the existence of mesoporous structure. On the basis of the isotherms shown in Fig. 8(a-d)), the BET surface area of NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-1, NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-2, NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-3 and NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-4 could be calculated to be 194.7712, 245.4938, 303.1532, 205.7607 m²/g, respectively. Although the NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF catalysts with different molar amounts of metal precursors display the same mesoporous architecture, the NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF-3 with minimal mean pore size possesses the maximum BET surface area, favoring sufficient exposure of the active sites for VHP adsorption and decomposition. Consequently, the initial enhanced activity with the addition of metal precursors is attributed to the enlarged BET surface area and increased mass loading of active components. The loss of activity with further addition of metal precursors is due to the aggregation of nanosheets caused by enlarged nanosheet size, therefore leading to insufficient exposure of active sites [44]. In addition, the catalytic mechanism of VHP decomposition using Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF has been analyzed. As shown in Table 1, the breakdown of VHP into water and oxygen involves H2O2 reduction or oxidation (single-electron transfer between the catalyst and the H2O2 molecule) [11,69,70]. This process is mediated by surface redox pairs (Mn+/M(n−1)+ or Mn+/M(n+1)+) that act as active centers for VHP decomposition [11,71,72]. The Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF catalyst with the extensive specific surface area provides multiple redox pairs, contributing to richer active sites for VHP decomposition. In addition, the pathway of VHP decomposition changes significantly with the enhancement of the electrophilicity of active sites and the dominant surface reaction evolves from H2O2 reduction to H2O2 oxidation. In comparison with the H2O2 oxidation, the H2O2 reduction is more thermodynamically favorable [73]. Therefore, the catalyst with weaker electron affinity would facilitate the reduction of H2O2, thus reducing the energy barrier for VHP decomposition reaction. The improved catalytic efficiency of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF results from the reduction in the energy barrier for VHP decomposition reaction caused by the introduction of Pt. This is because the VHP decomposition on NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF mainly proceeds via H2O2 oxidation, while the metallic Pt has less electrophilicity and it can promote the H2O2 reduction [74,75]. In the H2O2 reduction pathway, the O-O splitting reaction is the rate-limiting step [76]. The metallic Pt can act as an electron donor to weaken the O-O bond of H2O2, thereby accelerating the H2O2 dissociation. Meanwhile, the XPS results also prove that a strong electronic interaction of NiAlCrFe-LDHs and Pt, which facilitates electron transfer and enhances catalytic activity toward VHP decomposition resulting from optimized the adsorption of reaction intermediates. Overall, the NiAlCrFe-LDHs and Pt synergistically accelerate the VHP decomposition reaction by triggering simultaneous oxidation and reduction reactions of H2O2. 4 Conclusion In summary, we prepared the Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF catalyst using a simple one-step hydrothermal method and revealed its growth mechanism. The characterization results confirm the structure of catalyst consists of trace Pt-loading transition metal hydroxides nanosheets, which have an enlarged BET surface area and unique mesoporous architecture. The formation of the Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs nanosheets is believed to proceed via a dissolution-precipitation process and spontaneous reduction of Pt nanoparticles, in which the NF is not only chemically etched to form Ni2+ and it can also reduce Pt4+ ions to metallic Pt. Then, the obtained Ni2+ ions and metallic Pt co-precipitate with the hydrated metal hydroxides by hydrolysis of Al3+, Cr3+ and Fe3+ to generate Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs. The integration of Pt modifies the electronic structure of the catalyst and triggers simultaneous oxidation and reduction reactions of H2O2, thus decreasing the energy barrier for VHP decomposition reaction. Owing to the synergistic interaction of NiAlCrFe-LDHs and trifle Pt, the Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF catalyst exhibits superior VHP decomposition performance with catalytic decomposition time as low as 28 min. In addition, the Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF shows excellent cycling stability, indicating it holds great promise for widespread application in VHP disinfection. coredata.dc:description: Vaporized hydrogen peroxide (VHP) holds great promise for the decontamination of space environment. Nevertheless, following the decontamination process, highly concentrated VHP within confined spaces is harmful to the human body. Hence, trace Pt-loading (0.57 wt%) transition metal hydroxides nanosheets anchored on Ni foam (Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF) were prepared for VHP decomposition. Importantly, a strong electronic interaction between NiAlCrFe layer double hydroxides (NiAlCrFe-LDHs) and Pt was evidenced by XPS. Meanwhile, unique nanosheet-like morphology and rich mesoporous structure endow the catalyst with excellent performance. The catalytic activity of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF is approximately twice that of NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF and seven times that of Pt/NF. The improved catalytic efficiency of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF results from the reduction in energy barrier for VHP decomposition reaction caused by the introduction of trace Pt. After ten recycling experiments, this catalyst still shows good durability with no significant deterioration in VHP decomposition efficiency. Finally, the growth mechanism of Pt@NiAlCrFe-LDHs/NF was also proposed and discussed.
